title: Boxing, charity work, hanging with Monfils – what I get up to in the off-season
text:
Boxing, charity work, hanging with Monfils – what I get up to in the off-season

Boxing, charity work, hanging with Monfils – what I get up to in the off-season

As part of our series with the Women’s Tennis Association, the world’s top tennis players will write for Metro.co.uk on a rotational basis during each major tournament. For the final event of the year, Shiseido WTA Finals Shenzhen, Ukraine’s world No. 8 and defending champion Elina Svitolina reflects on her year and outlines her plans for the off-season.

This is the end of another long, gruelling season; one full of highs and lows.

On the one hand, I reached two Grand Slam semi-finals – I’d never gone that far in a major before this year – but I set my sights higher than that and it’s been a year where I’ve struggled to be fully fit.

I’ve had a knee problem since February, which disrupted my preparations for Roland Garros but I took a lot of confidence from runs to the semi-finals at Wimbledon and the US Open.

Elina Svitolina is looking to defend her WTA Finals title (Picture: WTA)

They obviously boosted my ranking but also gave me extra belief that my tennis is capable of reaching the level required to achieve my future goals.

Qualifying for the Shiseido WTA Finals Shenzhen – the final event of our season – is always a goal and I’m glad to have the opportunity to defend the title I won in Singapore 12 months ago.

Being among the top-eight players in the world is always a big honour. It’s a great chance to reflect on the fact you’ve had a good enough year to be part of this group. Given my injury problems this season, it’s particularly satisfying that I’ve managed to get here again.

Although I will be giving everything to win the title at the inaugural event in Shenzhen and my focus is not straying from the task at hand, I am definitely ready for a period of rest and recuperation after another long year.

I like to put my racquet away and do yoga and pilates at this time of year as well as some cardio-focused boxing classes but I will obviously be doing a lot of rehab work on my knee so it’s fully ready for the new season.

I’m not really planning a sunny getaway as such, I’ll spend most of my time off in Europe.

My boyfriend and ATP tennis player Gael Monfils still has a few weeks left of his season and he is still hoping to reach the season-ending ATP Finals in London – the men’s equivalent of the event I’ll be competing in this week.

Advertisement

Advertisement

He will also be heading to Madrid for the Davis Cup finals so I will be there to support him out there.

I’ll also take some time for myself and will head to Ukraine to see my family as well as host an auction for my charity, the Elina Svitolina Foundation, in Kiev in November.

Then in about a month’s time I will probably head out to Dubai to step up my pre-season preparations, building up my fitness and, of course, trying to work on my game.

I’ll be doing everything in my power to be 100% ready for the new season and it helps that these days I know exactly how I’m scheduling a year, so I don’t really need to worry about where I’ll be and when because it’s all second nature now I’m a little bit more experienced.

My coach, Andrew Bettles, is my regular hitting partner but we’ll also look to have five days or so in a month with other players in order to see if what we’ve been working on is working.

I’m normally in big cities so it’s quite easy to find other players to hit with.

Advertisement

For example, last year I was in London and doing some work at the National Training Centre and there would be some other English girls working down there who I could have training sessions with. The same will be true in Dubai.

We normally have a little think about who could be there and send a few messages out to them to see if they fancy getting together for a session.

I set my sights high and nothing will change for the new season.

Elina Svitolina fact file Age: 25

Nationality: Ukrainian

Current ranking: 8

Career-high ranking: 3

Best Grand Slam result: Semi-finals (US Open, 2019/Wimbledon, 2019)

My aim is to win a Grand Slam, to win as many titles as I can and become world No. 1. But I also really just want to improve my game.

I want to be physically strong, to be consistent, and that consistency will then bring the best out of me and allow me to get to the top of the women’s game.

That’s what I’m looking for and it’s important to be mentally fresh. Our seasons are the longest in sport so you have to be ready for a big, long slog. A period of rest will definitely help on that front.

I don’t want to get too far ahead of myself, though, and I’ve still got business to take care of this week. Let’s try and finish the season on a high.
